title: Betterbird V128.5.2 constantly freezing
content:
I am a relatively new user of Betterbird and installed v115.16.0 a few months ago and found it worked fantastically fast, especially the search function which was my main concern with Outlook as it was painfully slow at times and seemed to cause the program to hang or freeze at other times.

I invested a lot of time setting up and getting used to the new email client to manage multiple email accounts with multiple different signatures and contact lists. I have updated each time the program told me of an available update. Each time without any issue, updating to 115.16.1, then 115.16.2, then 115.17.0 without any issue.

However, I updated to 128.5.0 earlier this month and then everything went wrong. Betterbird just started freezing constantly, with the "(Not responding)" message coming up every time I tried to delete an email or start a search, taking 20 to 60 secs to become responsive again. Then it very quickly became completely unusable, taking 20 to 30 secs to respond when I just selected an email to view, and if I then clicked on something else before it had responded, it would completely freeze and I would have CTLR+ALT+DEL to kill the process and restart the program. It would appear to work again for 10 to 15 secs again before starting to do the same thing again.

I have attempted to uninstall and re-install the program using the older version when the program worked properly but then it came up with a message a start up telling me that I have to create and setup the entire program and email accounts again as the profiles were no longer compatible with the older version. As I didn't have the time or the patience to do that, I gave up and went back to Outlook for a couple weeks.

I then noted that 128.5.0 had been updated to 128.5.2 so I thought I would try again, assuming a bug had been fixed. I have installed 128.5.2, setting everything and all the email accounts up again from scratch and found that it was working properly again. It worked perfectly for 2 days and then the same problem all over again of hanging and freezing, especially when I am trying to delete a viewed email, taking up to 2 mins to become responsive after deleting an email, with a message at the bottom of the program saying "Moved 1 message to Trash". I then delete another email, with the same result, but then after it has deleted the second message, the first message suddenly re-appears and when I delete that again, the second message re-appears again.

When I CTLR+ALT+DEL, I can see that the process has orange or red indicators using 10%+ CPU and 30-40% Memory. This is 6-core 32GB RAM system that runs and handles everything else I do with ease.

Sorry for the long post, but hopefully all the extra info will be of assistance. I really liked the program for the couple months that it worked perfectly for me, but now I am just out of ideas.
creator: AussieCabling

title: Sudden Gmail problem sending mail. "sending of the message failed. Peer's Certificate issuer is not recognized" and "Unknown Identity.. The certificate is not trusted"
content:
For many months, I've successfully used Thunderbird to access all my eMail accounts including those on Gmail, Yahoo, and on my personal InMotionHosting account, www.LArents.biz. Two days ago, I suddenly could no longer send messages from either of my Win7 desktop machines.

The most obvious problem is that I get an error message when saving an outgoing message as a draft or saving outgoing message to the sent-mail folder.

I suspect it may be a result of a recent Microsoft update to my Windows7 machine. There is also the possibility that Norton 360 installed on both (all) machines could be troublemaker; I've noticed that Norton has significantly updated the "look" of their portal on Christmas Day '24.

'A new Thunderbird installation on my Win10 desktop machine seems to work just fine.'

The Thunderbird settings appear identical between the Win10 and Win7 desktops, yet on the Win7 desktop I get messages like these: * "sending of the message failed. Peer's Certificate issuer is not recognized"

  • "Legitimate banks, stores, and other public sites will not ask you to do this. .Unknown Identity.. The certificate is not trusted because it hasn't been verified as issued by a trusted authority using a secure signature.

Suggestions as to possible cause & solutions?

Note main Win7 machine has quad processor, 16 GB of RAM, 500 GB SSD and Norton360 protection.

title: Unable to send Mail from Onetel account, only receive.
content:
Hello Firefox helpers.

I have had a Onetel e-mail address for over 25years, OneTel was acquired sometime ago by TalkTalk and this may have been when the issue started.

I can only, at the moment, receive e-mails to OneTel when using Thunderbird, I cannot send from the account when I use the Thunderbird/Mozilla template.

After many hours of trying to work out why this was happening, with the help of an IT angel, she discovered that Thunderbird was not connected to the OneTel outgoing Server port (number 25) and thus nothing could be sent. How do I ask Thunderbird to connect to Port #25?

At present, I'm sending from another account and copying in my OneTel address.

Any help with this would be gratefully received.

Regards, Dick Goodwin.

title: Email privacy and protection, IMAP versus local folders
content:
My provider uses IMAP, not POP3. I am transitioning to a new computer. My entire work and personal emails over the last 10 years are on this computer. A loss of emails would be really, really bad for my work. I use my Thunderbird account on two devices: a main laptop and a small travel laptop. It's nice to have them synched, but not essential due to limited use of my travel laptop.


Currently all of my old emails are in IMAP folders on the new computer. My questions:

(1) Which is better protected from loss of emails, IMAP folders or local folders? On the one hand, I occasionally destroy a computer by doing something dumb like spilling water on it. But does it ever happen that a provider permanently loses emails, like a major server crash?

(2) To what extent is loss of privacy an issue with IMAP storage folders? Is there any history of privacy incidents with IMAP folders?

(3) If I move emails from IMAP to local folders and then delete the IMAP folders, will my emails be permanently saved in the local folders? I did an experiment and the answer seems to be yes.

(4) Considering the above questions, is it best to store emails in IMAP or local folders? Is there any significant difference?

title: Thunderbird loses IMAP connection
content:
Every time I run Thunderbird, it appears to lose its IMAP connection(s) after 10-15 minutes. I've tried varying the number of cached connections from 1 to 10 with no difference in behavior.

Restarting Thunderbird will restore connectivity temporarily, until the entire process starts over again.

It seems to be correlated to saving a copy of sent messages. The sending process times out while the message is being saved to the Sent folder after the SMTP sending is complete.

Once this happens, new mail doesn't appear, moving mail between folders has no effect, and some (but not all) messages can't be retrieved from the server.
